Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: New Site of I/UCRC Safety, Security, and Rescue Research Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of North Carolina at Charlotte's site for the Safety, Security and Rescue Research I/UCRC intends to contribute to the mission of the existing center to conduct integrative, multi-disciplinary research in autonomous systems to improve homeland security and emergency response. The site plans to extend the scope of SSR to healthcare, energy, material handling, and manufacturing, by focusing on human safety, injury prevention, and patient care. The new SSR I/UCRC site intends to address areas including autonomous and guided robot actions for both sensing and manipulation under high-level human control, multi-agent, integration of real-time multi-modal sensory data, secure real-time computational analysis of safety critical SSR scenarios.


SSR Technologies are having world-wide impact in both the private and government sector. Moreover, application of these technologies is having impact that touches individual citizens. The University of North Carolina at Charlotte's Site of the SSR I/UCRC intends to extend the research outcomes it brings to the center to a new set of industries both regionally and nationally not currently represented in the center drawing upon complementary research domains. The site intends to leverage its I/UCRC site and strong NSF-funded programs on broadening participation in computing (e.g., the STARS Alliance) and REU Site by providing opportunities to engage undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and encourage them to enter graduate study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established a new site at UNC Charlotte of the multi-university Industry University Cooperative Research Center: Safety, Security, and Rescue Research Center (I/UCRC SSR-RC). The SSR-RC involved the University of Minnesota (lead), the University of Denver, and the University of Pennsylvania. The Center’s main objective was to facilitate technology transfer by focusing on medium-term research and development in safety, security, and rescue (SSR) research that leveraged pre-existing long-term research results, held the commercial interest of the corporate members of the Center and met the needs of public sector responders.

The new UNC Charlotte site aligned its mission with the existing center’s mission on SSR but also extended the scope of SSR to a broader range of industry sectors, including healthcare, energy, and manufacturing, focusing on human safety. The site research activities ranged from image processing, machine learning, and robotic manipulation related to nuclear inspection, to perception of cluttered environments, to haptic guidance for aiding surgical training, and to knowledge discovery. The site also facilitated collaborative research with researchers from partner sites in the Center, including shape-based object recognition based on touch via continuum manipulation and systematic testing of autonomous robots operating in uncertain and dynamic environments. Research results were published in top robotics journals and conferences in a number of papers. The site supported and trained a large number of students, including female students, from undergraduate to PhD levels, and graduated a number of PhD students. The site was also actively engaged in outreach activities to K-12 students, from hosting lab visits, demos, to engaging high-school students in research training during summers, and to bringing demos to classrooms in local schools.
